subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit 4.x and support for Java 1.4
msgSnippet: ... Once  JUnit 4.xxx is back ported it would be possible for you to write your own base class implementation just as you describe. From experience in the .NET
messageBody:
On 9/13/06, Marvin Toll <MarvinToll@...> wrote:
>
>
> At the risk of criticism for replying to my own post ...
>
> If a version of JUnit 4 were made available for Java 1.4 - my
> personal preferrence might be to have a base class extension style
> of API with call back methods similar to JUnit 3. (Note: A more
> standard call back syntax ... i.e. use preTest()/postTest() [or even
> preTestCB()/postTestCB()] to wrap setUp()/testDown() could be
> favored.)


Once JUnit 4.xxx is back ported it would be possible for you to write your
own base class implementation just as you describe.

From experience in the .NET world there is some real advantage to declaring
tests using Attributes/Annotation. It makes it possible to derive your
derive your test class from some other class.

This provides a comfortable migration (learning) path for developers
> and, more importantly, provides a strategy to leverage all of the
> convenience extensions companies have built upon JUnit


Martin it sounds like what you want is an upgraded Junit 3.8.1 with better
support for fixture setup/teardown. Is that the case?

What I want is the declarative approach for building tests (pioneered by
NUnit, used by MBUnit and TestNG) made available to for Java 1.4.

If one prefers JavaDoc annotations you can always use TestNG. Why
> go down that path a second time?


Because TestNG isn't tightly integrated into Eclipse - so not only do I have
to sell my dev team on making the change I also have to sell build services
on the idea. I have prove that TestNG should be a another dependancy in our
build chain. In addition JUnit 4 has the profile that gaurantees the support
libraries like JMock et al. will eventually be support it. I'm not convinced
that TestNG has the same momentum (sorry Cedric). This is a little bit like
the .Net world NUnit is the leading tool with the most support, while MBUnit
is consistently the innovator. As a result the MBUnit bend over backwards to
be compatible with NUnit so that tests and tools move from NUnit with no
effort.

Cheers
Mark
